image.altText: A young woman in profile at the Newcastle waterfront.

props.synopsis: To understand why 30-somethings feel like they're struggling financially, the ABC analysed five factors — housing, healthcare, debt, tax, and income. The data reveals this generation is caught in an economic perfect storm.

title.children: Are you 30 and worse off than your parents' generation? Here's the data

image.altText: The AFL logo on the side of a building, partially obscured by a tree branch.

props.synopsis: When it comes to illicit substances, the AFL runs two drug policies side-by-side — one to prevent doping and one to protect its players.

title.children: The AFL runs two drug policies side-by-side for its players. Here's how they work

image.altText: Fiji's prime minister is shown wearing a grey suit and red and green striped tie.

props.synopsis: Fiji's prime minister speaks with the ABC about the relationship between China and the Pacific nation as Beijing's role in the country comes under intense scrutiny.

title.children: Chinese police kicked out of Fiji over PM being  'uncomfortable' with presence in the region

image.altText: The logo for Meta is printed on a white box floating from the ceiling

props.synopsis: Posts that have been fact-checked and proven false are slipping through Meta's net, a new report alleges. And the tech giant could be in breach of their code of conduct.

title.children: New complaint against Meta claims Facebook is failing to keep its misinformation promises to Australians

image.altText: An aerial view of a steel truss bridge that has fallen on top of a container ship in a river.

props.synopsis: The chequered record of the ship's owner in the Baltimore bridge tragedy offers a glimpse of the "murky world" of tax havens and worker exploitation in global shipping.

title.children: Tax havens and worker exploitation behind shipping company in Baltimore disaster

image.altText: A family poses for a photograph at a 17th birthday party. Parents have their arms around their two sons, and two grandchildren

props.synopsis: A family of seven that fled Iran 12 years ago fear they could be forced to return if the government succeeds in passing tough new deportation laws.

title.children: 'Mama, what's happening to us?': Family fears forced return to Iran if government passes new laws

image.altText: Two people in a doorway.

props.synopsis: Small towns across Italy are selling homes for just 1 euro to survive terminal population decline. Foreign Correspondent travelled to Sicily to see what life's really like after you buy one.

title.children: Would you move to a Sicilian village for a 1-euro house? Here’s what happened when Krastina did

image.altText: A large crowd watches King Gizzard play live at Splendour In The Grass 2023.

props.synopsis: The shock cancellation of this year’s Splendour In The Grass music festival may signal the end of the “multi-genre, something for everyone” approach to live music, according to an expert in the field.

title.children: 'It's terrifying': Music industry reacts to Splendour's shock cancellation

image.altText: Ice on a curved globe

props.synopsis: Melting ice in Greenland and Antarctica is changing Earth's spin, which may help experts with a tricky international timekeeping dilemma, a new study suggests.

title.children: Melting ice caps are putting the brakes on Earth's spin and affecting how we keep time

image.altText: A man speaks into a microphone on a foreign television channel.

props.synopsis: Australian officials have labelled the Russian election an "insult to democracy", but Port Hedland's Adrian McRae was full of praise for Mr Putin.

title.children: WA councillor praises Putin's 'transparent and comprehensive' election win during appearance on Russian TV

image.altText: A scene late at night of a bridge mid collapsing.

props.synopsis: In less than half-an-hour, a cargo ship had left its port, suffered a power failure and destroyed Baltimore's Key Bridge. It was all captured on video.

title.children: It only took 30 seconds for Baltimore's largest bridge to collapse. Here's how the disaster unfolded

image.altText: Queen Camilla smiles as she greets two women.

props.synopsis: The late Queen Elizabeth II could have had no idea quite how central Queen Camilla would become barely a year into the reign of Charles III — not just to her son, but to the United Kingdom.

title.children: From giving the King's speech to handing out Maundy Money this is how Camilla is stepping up

image.altText: Andrew Giles stands next to Clare O'Neil at a press conference

props.synopsis: There's a sense of panic that comes with the prime minister's office walking senior government ministers to a press conference. It sends a clear signal: it might not be the prime minister speaking but his office is certainly taking charge.

title.children: Escorted by their boss's staff, ministers left looking like children being marched from the principal's office

image.altText: Gotye and Kimbra star in the film clip for song Somebody That I Used To Know.

props.synopsis: Artists Peking Duk, Gotye and Angus and Julia Stone were among the victims of accountant Damien Luscombe, who worked for a Melbourne-based firm specialising in managing finances for clients in the entertainment industry.

title.children: Musician Gotye says he forgives accountant who stole almost $500k of his earnings

image.altText: A rainbow flag is held up by hundreds of people at a pride street parade

props.synopsis: MPs in Thailand voted overwhelmingly in favour the marriage equality bill, but did not approve inclusion of the word "parent" in addition to "father and mother" in the law.

title.children: Thailand set to become first country to legalise marriage rights for people of any gender in South-East Asia

image.altText: Hands holds one of four cheese wheels with a sheep picture on top.

props.synopsis: Pecora Dairy wins the 17th annual President's Medal at the Sydney Royal Easter Show, with a Spanish-style, semi-hard cheese made at Robertson.

title.children: Raw sheep's milk cheese receives the nation's highest food honour, but just a decade ago it was illegal to make it

props.synopsis: YouTube blocks access in India to an episode of Foreign Correspondent about Sikh separatism after a demand from the Indian government.

title.children: YouTube blocks Foreign Correspondent episode after Indian's government's demand, weeks before election

image.altText: The doors of the Todd Tavern are seen smashed.

props.synopsis: The Northern Territory government will declare an "emergency situation" in Alice Springs and send 58 extra police officers into the town after several violent incidents this week.

title.children: Youth curfew announced for Alice Springs CBD following unrest

image.altText: Image of children in a classroom beside a girl with a backpack on orange squares

props.synopsis: Following revelations an independent school teacher who sent sexually explicit emails to a former student faced no disciplinary action, questions have been asked about how all schools handle allegations against teachers.

title.children: When teachers face allegations of harm to children, this is how they're investigated

image.altText: William Tyrrell's foster mother in a black jumper and white shirt underneath, walking with her husband outside court

props.synopsis: The foster mother and father received good behaviour bonds and convictions after being found guilty of intimidating the child on a number of occasions, while also being fined $1,500 over a dummy bid placed at an auction.

title.children: William Tyrrell's former foster parents handed convictions after intimidating different child

image.altText: O'Neil gestures with one hand as she responds to a question.

props.synopsis: Clare O'Neil has been grilled on reports the Department of Home Affairs boss left her office in tears after an altercation over the immigration detainee saga.

title.children: Opposition presses Clare O'Neil over whether home affairs boss left her office in tears

image.altText: An electronic billboard advertises the Mega Millions and Powerball jackpots in Iowa.

props.synopsis: The odds of winning the jackpot are 1 in 302.6 million.

title.children: US lottery entrant takes home $1.7 billion jackpot after three month winnless streak

image.altText: GettyImages-2054046622

props.synopsis: In one short hour, the AFL confirmed what had been an open secret in the Aussie Rules world — that players who tested positive for illicit drugs were sitting out games with concocted injuries. It's a system designed to protect players, but at what cost to integrity?

title.children: The AFL is at pains to protect its players from the consequences of their own actions — but in doing so, they're lying to the fans

image.altText: Sam Drummond is smiling. He is wearing glasses and a blue button up shirt, and is standing in front of bookshelves.

props.synopsis: It's Pay Day! Lawyer, disability advocate and author Sam Drummond reveals he doesn't enjoy spending money, and a valuable lesson he learned early on — not having a lot of money is actually expensive.

title.children: Sam Drummond learned early on that not having a lot of money is actually expensive — that's why he has only two bank accounts

image.altText: A woman with a brown bob wears a light blue blazer and speaks at a press conference, unsmiling.

props.synopsis: Telstra's triple-0 outage on March 1 was the combination of a technical fault, an issue in the backup process and a communication error that occurred in the heat of the moment, Telstra CEO Vicki Brady says.

title.children: 'Unacceptable' Telstra triple-0 outage caused by multiple technical issues, investigation concludes

image.altText: Gallagher, tehan faruqi graphic

props.synopsis: The Senate has rejected the government's bid to rush extraordinary immigration powers through the parliament.

title.children: Senate blocks government's attempt to rush extraordinary immigration powers through parliament

image.altText: People stand with heads bowed in front of a large cross draped with purple fabric

props.synopsis: A construction worker says a shift-change kept him from being on the bridge with the doomed men as officials work to confirm their identities. This is what we know about the victims so far.

title.children: 'Wonderful family people, spouses, children': What we know about the Baltimore bridge collapse victims

image.altText: Cash lays on a kitchen table beside a cup of tea and a list of bills owing

props.synopsis: The annual rate of inflation remained steady in February, at 3.4 per cent, while underlying inflation picked up slightly, to 3.9 per cent.

title.children: The annual rate of inflation remained steady in February, at 3.4 per cent

image.altText: a man smiling in front of a painting smiling

props.synopsis: Indigenous Australian art is celebrated globally. But who reaps the profits? Indigenous Australians are advised that this story contains the images and names of people who have died.

title.children: This late artist's egg-blue canvas sold for nearly $200,000 in New York. Back home, his family received nothing from the sale

image.altText: Putin standing in the dark wearing black lighting a candle on a gold church candle holder

props.synopsis: Ukraine was being blamed for the attack on a Moscow theatre without evidence just hours after it happened. It's an allegation that feeds into Russia's disinformation campaign in the Ukraine war.

title.children: Hours after the Moscow theatre shooting Ukraine was being blamed, feeding into Russia's disinformation war

image.altText: a man in swimming costume stretches hands outwards on a beach

props.synopsis: A Sydneysider swims for 31 hours without stopping to complete a journey that long-distance legends Des Renford and Susie Maroney were both forced to abandon.

title.children: Man, 64, becomes first to swim from Newcastle to Sydney unaided, braving bluebottle stings 'the whole time'

image.altText: Smart cities of near future.

props.synopsis: Planning decisions in Australia can take years to get off the ground. Experts say artificial intelligence could change that.

title.children: If you think artificial intelligence doesn't impact the way you live, think again
